source:
# Forbes 2000 Global Companies - An Analysis

The Forbes 2000 list is a ranking of the world's largest and most powerful public companies, based on a composite of sales, profits, assets and market value. The "Forbes 2000 Global Companies - An Analysis" project will take a closer look at these companies, and provide an in-depth analysis of their financial performance, industry trends, and market conditions. This project will utilize data on the companies' revenue, profit, assets, market value, and other financial metrics, as well as information on their industry, location, and size. By analyzing this data, we will be able to identify patterns, trends, and insights into the performance of these companies and the broader global economy. Whether you're a business professional, an investor, or just interested in understanding the dynamics of the global economy, this project will provide valuable insights and a comprehensive look at the world's top companies. Join us as we dive into the data and explore the story of the Forbes 2000 Global Companies.

The Libraries used in the project are:
- Matplotlib(for visualization of data) Explore
- Seaborn (used alongside Matplotlib for visualization) Explore
- Numpy (used for operations on numeric data) Explore
- Pandas (used for utilising DataFrames and organising the data)Explore
- Jovian (used for downloading dataset and to run, save and upload the Notebook)Explore

To install all required libraries,run the following Command:
- pip install matplotlib seaborn numpy pandas jovian --upgrade

The following Tasks are implemented in the Project:
- Data Preparation and Cleaning
- Exploratory Analysis and Visualization
- Asking and Answering Questions
- Inferences and Conclusion
- References and Future Work

## Downloading the Dataset

There are several ways to download a dataset and use it into Jupyter Notebook, which includes downloading it manually and uploading it. But here we use a helper library, e.g., opendatasets, which contains a collection of curated datasets and provides a helper function for direct download. We use this helper library to download our file.

First, we need to install the opendataset library.
Let's begin by downloading the data, and listing the files within the dataset. For that, we must need to specify the URL we are going to use.
Now that we have the dataset URL and the library, we need to import the library to download our file.

## Data Preparation and Cleaning

The raw data is now obtained.First we need to clean and simplify the data in order to prepare it for Analysis.

The .csv file which we already have from Kaggle will be converted into a Pandas DataFrame and will be cleaned to extract only the columns which will be needed for analysis.

Let us import the pandas to read csv file and for plotting, import matplotlib seaborn and their modules.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

sns.set_style('darkgrid')

Now we need to read our csv file into a variable.

It helps us to access our file so easily in future too.

source:
So now we have our Forbes 2000 top global companies data in tabular form.

Lets just derive basic info's from our dataset.

Before that, we should rename our coloumns for better access.

forbes_data.rename(columns = {'2022 Ranking': '2022_ranking'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Organization Name': 'org_name'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Industry': 'industry'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Country': 'country'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Year Founded': 'year'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'CEO': 'ceo'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Revenue (Billions)': 'revenue'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Profits (Billions)': 'profit_billions'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Assets (Billions)': 'asset_billions'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Market Value (Billions)': 'market_value_billions'}, inplace =True)
forbes_data.rename(columns = {'Total Employees': 'total_emp'}, inplace =True)

source:
Here, we can see that our data contains a total of 11 coloumns and the datatype of each coloumn is different(integer, floating point number, object).

We also have 1999 entries, which means data of 2000 companies starting from 0-1999(Rows).

Using describe(), we found out the central tendancy of our data. At first, we can say that our standard deviation is so high.

We also need to make sure that there is exactly one entry per company, that is, all companies are unique.

Now we know that there is no duplicate entry, ie, every company is unique.

Lets just make sure that there is no null values too.

text/plain:
2022_ranking             0
org_name                 0
industry                 0
country                  0
year                     0
ceo                      0
revenue                  0
profit_billions          0
asset_billions           0
market_value_billions    0
total_emp                0
dtype: int64

source: So now we know that there is no missing values in the dataset too, we are good to go.

## Exploratory Analysis and Visualization

Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is an approach to analyze the data using visual techniques. It is used to discover trends, patterns, or to check assumptions with the help of statistical summary and graphical representations.

source:
Even though we can find some insight from this plot, it's kinda messy.

Now, we are going to distribute organization revenue using plot.
Now, lets find out the countries and their profits.

sns.set(style="darkgrid")
sns.set_palette("pastel")
plt.figure(figsize=(15,45))
ax = sns.boxplot(y='country', x='profit_billions', data=forbes_data)
ax.set_xlim(right=40)
plt.title("Financial performance by location", fontsize=20)
plt.xlabel("Profit", fontsize=15)
plt.ylabel("Country", fontsize=15)
plt.xticks(rotation=0, fontsize=12)
plt.show()
Now, let's use scatterplot to find the various industries and their profit.

forbes_data_groupedbyindustry = forbes_data.groupby('industry').mean()
plt.figure(figsize = (15,5))
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.title('Financial performance by industry')
plt.xlabel('Industry')
plt.ylabel('Profit')
sns.set(style ="darkgrid")
sns.scatterplot(x='industry', y='profit_billions', data=forbes_data_groupedbyindustry, color = "blue")
plt.show()
Now, we can check the relationship between revenue and profit, and their ranking on forbes list.

sns.set(style ="darkgrid")
plt.figure(figsize = (15,8))
sns.scatterplot(x='revenue', y='profit_billions', hue='2022_ranking', data=forbes_data)
plt.show()
Now, we can check the relationship between a company's industry and it's financial performance. For that,

sns.set(style="darkgrid")
sns.set_palette("pastel")
plt.figure(figsize=(15,8))
sns.scatterplot(x='asset_billions', y='profit_billions', data=forbes_data)
plt.title("Financial performance vs Assets", fontsize=20)
plt.xlabel("Assets", fontsize=15)
plt.ylabel("Profit", fontsize=15)
plt.show()
Now, visualising different industries to gain more insights.

banking_data = forbes_data[forbes_data.industry == 'Banking']
material_data = forbes_data[forbes_data.industry == 'Materials']
chemical_data = forbes_data[forbes_data.industry == 'Chemicals']
Now we can add another industry to get more understanding,
Now, we can draw a simple line plot with industry and their market_value_billions.
This is kinda messy, right?. We can use another method.

source: Now, lets dive into the origin of the company and the industry.

sns.set(style = "darkgrid")
plt.figure(figsize = (10,20))
plt.title('Year of origin and Industry')
ax = sns.boxplot(x=forbes_data.year, y=forbes_data.industry)
ax.set_xlim(left=1800)
plt.show();
Now that we have explored various relationships within the dataset, we are good to go.

source:
## Inferences and Conclusion

- Forbes is a global media company that publishes a variety of business, financial, and lifestyle news and information. 
- The dataset obtained had 2000 entries, ie, 2000 rows and 11 coloumns.
- The 11 rows are comprised of include 4 float, 2 int and 5 object data type.
- Found out the central tendancy and noticed that the standard deviation is so high for every coloumn except profit
- Primary inference concluded that the gaining of profit for companies over the period of time was very marginal.
- Analysed that there is exactly one entry per company, resulting in no duplications.
- Found out that there is no null values too.
- Inferred that every industry has multiple entries of companies atleast, ie, each industry has 2 or more companies to their section.
- Banking industry had twice the number of companies than any other industry listed to it's name(289). 
- Found out number of companies in a country and realised that United States has twice amount of leap towards it than any other country(584).
- created a histogram showing the frequency of different revenue values among the organizations present in the dataset and almost all(~1750) organizations have profit around 100 billion margin.
- Created a boxplot to analyse the profit margin by country and US had the most of them.
- Created a scatterplot to check the relationship between various industry and their profits and Automotive had the lowest and Oil and Gas production had the highest.
- Checked the relationship between revenue and profit, and their ranking on forbes list and found out among 800 organizations had their profit below 20 million.
- Created a scatter plot to find the relationship between Profit and Assets of an Organization and realised that most of them are skewed towards 0-20 billion in profit and 0-1000 billion in assets.
- Found out the relationship between various types of industries and their revenue and noticed that banking industry had the major upperhand.
- Drew a simple line plot and then scatterplot to understand the relationship between industries and their market value. Almost every industry had their market value below 500 billion.
- Found out the relationship between year of origin of the Organisation and industry and noticed almost every industry was between 1950 and 2000.
- Found out the total revenue of all organisations in the forbes list which is 47749 billion.
- Found out the 3 countries with the highest profit, which is, Saudi Arabia, United States and China
- Found out the 5 industries with the lowest market value,ie, Construction, Banking, Retailing, Trading Companies, Food Markets.
- Found the Gross Margin Ratio for top 10 profit gaining companies, which is 0.263150, 0.265540, 0.325256, 0.295274, 0.384965, 0.259597, 0.232048, 0.338205, 0.333842, 0.2060 respectively.
- Found out number of unique industries in forbes list, which is 29.

From this analysis, we can conclude that,
- Companies in certain industries tend to have higher revenues and profits than those in others. For example, technology companies may have higher profits than companies in more traditional industries like manufacturing or retail.
- Companies with higher revenues and profits may also tend to have higher assets and market values. This suggests that these companies are financially strong and are perceived positively by investors.
- Companies that have been in business for a longer period of time may tend to have higher revenues, profits, assets, and market values compared to newer companies. This could be due to the benefits of experience and brand recognition.
- Companies with larger number of employees tend to have higher revenues, however, this may not always be the case.
- Companies with higher profits tend to have higher market value, This suggest that investors are willing to pay more for companies that are more profitable.
